questions.question: What does outage probability represent in wireless communication?

answers.a: The likelihood that a transmitter will fail
answers.b: The probability that the received signal falls below a minimum threshold
answers.c: The probability of achieving maximum signal quality
answers.d: The average power of the transmitted signal

explanations.a: Incorrect – this refers to hardware reliability, not signal performance.
explanations.b: Correct – outage probability is the chance the received signal is below a set threshold.
explanations.c: Incorrect – this is unrelated to outage probability definition.
explanations.d: Incorrect – outage probability is not about average transmitted power.

questions.question: What is the coverage area in a wireless communication system?

answers.a: The area where a signal can be received with acceptable quality
answers.b: The area within a transmitter’s physical boundary
answers.c: The area where all users have maximum signal strength
answers.d: The area beyond which the signal strength is zero

explanations.a: Correct – coverage area is where signal meets minimum quality requirements.
explanations.b: Incorrect – physical boundary does not define RF coverage.
explanations.c: Incorrect – not all locations have maximum signal.
explanations.d: Incorrect – some signal may still be present beyond coverage area.

questions.question: Outage probability depends on which of the following?

explanations.a: Partially correct – but not the only factor.
explanations.b: Partially correct – but not the only factor.
explanations.c: Correct – both the target threshold and distance affect outage probability.

questions.question: If a cell has a low outage probability, which of the following is likely true?

answers.a: The cell has poor signal coverage
answers.b: The cell provides consistent signal quality

explanations.a: Incorrect – low outage means better coverage.
explanations.b: Correct – low outage means fewer drops and stable performance.
explanations.c: Incorrect – high outage probability would cause dropped calls.
explanations.d: Incorrect – low outage does not indicate lack of transmitters.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common method to improve coverage in a wireless network?

explanations.a: Correct – more power extends range and improves coverage.
explanations.c: Incorrect – higher frequencies suffer higher pathloss.
explanations.d: Incorrect – higher outage probability means worse coverage.

questions.question: In practical systems, outage probability is often reduced by:

explanations.a: Correct – more base stations reduce distance and improve coverage.
explanations.b: Incorrect – smaller antennas usually reduce gain.
explanations.c: Incorrect – while less load helps, it doesn’t directly reduce outage probability.
explanations.d: Incorrect – more noise makes performance worse.

questions.question: A higher target signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) threshold generally leads to:

explanations.a: Incorrect – higher threshold means it’s harder to meet the requirement.
explanations.b: Correct – higher SNR target increases the chance of outage.
explanations.c: Incorrect – SNR threshold affects outage probability.
explanations.d: Incorrect – higher threshold usually reduces coverage.

questions.question: Which environment is most likely to have smaller coverage for the same transmit power?

explanations.a: Incorrect – rural areas usually have larger coverage.
explanations.b: Correct – dense urban areas have more obstructions and higher pathloss.
explanations.c: Incorrect – suburban areas usually have moderate coverage.
explanations.d: Incorrect – indoor hall coverage depends heavily on building materials.
